Name: Romans
History: The Romans controlled one of the largest empires of the ancient world, stretching at its peak from southern Scotland to the Sahara Desert, and containing between 60 million and 80 million inhabitants, one quarter of the Earth's population at that time. Rome also remained one of the strongest nations on earth for almost 800 years. The Romans were the supreme builders of the ancient world, excelled at siege warfare and had an exquisite infantry and navy.

Technologies.Name: Marian Reforms
Technologies.History: Gaius Marius turned the roman legions into a professional force.
Technologies.Description: Upgrades Swordsmen and Spearmen to Marian Legionaries, with +10% hit points, attack and vision over Elite Swordsmen.

Technologies.Name: Logistics
Technologies.History: Roman skill in military logistics and their large manpower pool allowed them to quickly mobilize forces and replace loses.

Technologies.Name: Gladius Hispaniensis
Technologies.History: Introduction of the Iberian Gladius shortsword increased Roman infantry effectiveness.

Heroes.Name: Consular Bodyguard
Heroes.Description: Heavy Cavalry. Deals x1.5 damage to Unique Units.

CivBonuses.Name: Triarius
CivBonuses.History: Early roman armies were largely formed by hoplite-like spearmen, a tradition partly continued by the Triarii, veteran reserve units of the roman legions.
CivBonuses.Description: Stronger replacement for the generic spearman.

CivBonuses.Name: Roman Legions
CivBonuses.History: Roman legions were trained as to fight a cohesive and flexible force.
CivBonuses.Description: Legion Barracks units upgrade through shared techs. Swordsmen -20% train time, Skirmishers and Heavy Cavalry +1 pierce armor.

CivBonuses.Name: Military Construction
CivBonuses.History: Roman armies were responsible for the construction of their fortifications and often a variety of other structures.
CivBonuses.Description: Villagers build economic and civic structures, while infantry build defensive and military ones.

CivBonuses.Name: Scientific Adaptation
CivBonuses.History: The Romans were eager to adapt good ideas from their neighbours and enemies.
CivBonuses.Description: Structures, Ships and Ranged Siege Weapons +10% range, vision, accuracy and hit points for each phase researched.

TeamBonuses.Name: Socii
TeamBonuses.History: Roman allies, especially the Italian ones, often provided the majority of soldiers in Roman armies.
TeamBonuses.Description: Barracks -25% build time for each phase researched (currently not shared).

Structures.Name: Auxiliary Camp
Structures.Description: Trains Auxiliary units. Has no territory restrictions. Replaces the Stables.
